attributes.action: Require every garment sold in the UK to include a 'Carbon Checker' label
attributes.background:
We want legislation enacted that will require every UK garment to feature a 'Carbon Checker' label. This will enable shoppers to factor how green a garment is into their purchasing decisions. 

The 'Carbon Checker' label would show how environmentally friendly a garment is, on a scale of A-E.
attributes.additional_details:
The fashion industry is one of the most polluting in the world. It contributes 1.2bn tonnes of CO2 per year and the Government does not have adequate plans in place to combat it. 

Two-thirds of emissions from UK clothing occur overseas. Complex supply chains mean cotton is grown, woven and dyed on different continents then transported many miles to market. 

If consumers can factor how eco-friendly a garment is into their purchasing decision, this should encourage the fashion industry to prioritise greener manufacturing methods.

departments.name: Department for Environment, Food and Rural Affairs

attributes.action: Increase TfL emergency funding to help protect bus routes in London
attributes.background: The Government has required Transport for London (TfL) to make savings as a condition of its emergency funding, and as a result TfL is proposing to reduce the number of kilometres travelled by its buses by 4% by 2024/25. The Govt should increase TfL’s funding so it doesn’t have to cut bus routes.
attributes.additional_details:
The proposed loss of many routes will surely impact many bus users, many of whom cannot use any other form of transport (for physical reasons). It will surely increase transit costs, making transport unaffordable for many.

The reduction of bus mileage will also result in increased car and taxi use, which will in turn release more pollutants into the environment.

departments.name: Department for Transport

attributes.action: Ban the sale of wood burners in the UK
attributes.background:
Air pollution in the UK is linked to 40,000 deaths.

Indoor air pollution has increased, though domestic combustion.

Banning the sale of wood burners protects the health and safety of citizens and neighbourhoods.
attributes.additional_details:
Small particles (PM2.5) coming from wood burners enter the human body  and are a health hazard. 

There has already been regulation against the sale of 'wet wood' and coal. 

New regulations are due in Jan 2022 for 'Eco designs' that still emit dangerous amounts of pollution. 

Let's go one further. 

Let's ban the sale of these household hazards.

departments.name: Department for Environment, Food and Rural Affairs

attributes.action: Introduce a ban on the most polluting fibres in fashion by 2025
attributes.background: Last year, 4.2bn items of clothing were sold in the UK. The majority made from conventional cotton, generic viscose and virgin polyester; fibres with a huge carbon footprint. How is this allowed at a time of climate emergency? We’re calling on the government to ban the most polluting fibres by 2025.
attributes.additional_details: Fashion accounts for 10% of global CO2 emissions yet is unregulated. A main factor is usage of conventional cotton, generic viscose and virgin polyester - fibres produced using vast amounts of pesticides, chemicals, water and fossil fuels. We need regulation fast. A ban is easy to enact and 4 years reasonable time to transition to eco-friendlier alternatives. The result; a significant reduction in CO2 emissions, soil- and water pollution, and a tangible positive impact on the planet.

departments.name: Department for Environment, Food and Rural Affairs

attributes.action: Legalise Human Composting (Natural Organic Reduction)
attributes.background: Natural Organic Reduction, legal in 4 US states, is the gentle transformation of the human body into soil. Many feel a symbolic and spiritual significance of returning to the soil, and loved ones have a sense of ceremony; they can scatter, plant trees with, or donate remains to ecological projects.
attributes.additional_details:
In the UK 80% of us choose cremation, with around 470,000 per year. For every one around 245 kg of carbon and many pollutants is released, totalling 115,000 tonnes yearly. Cremation is an important option, but Human Composting provides an environmentally friendly alternative. Fuel is saved and the carbon and nutrients of the body are kept. 

UK residents deserve the full spectrum of deathcare options, allowing everybody the chance to have their final wishes met. Therefore NOR should be legalised.

departments.name: Department of Health and Social Care

attributes.action: Make Noise Nuisance and light pollution a Criminal Offence
attributes.background: To have the police investigate noise nuisance allegations and light pollution eg security lights instead of Council Environmental health.
attributes.additional_details: Change the way noise nuisance and light pollution is dealt with and view it as anti-social behavior and dealt with by the police. The consideration of mental health implications needs to be addressed, bearing in mind lockdown is exacerbating the issue.

departments.name: Ministry of Justice

attributes.action: Ensure all UK's plastic waste  is processed and recycled in the UK
attributes.background: Prevent the export of plastic waste produced in the UK from being exported to other countries to deal. We are environmentally obliged to deal with our own waste products and not saddle other countries with the burden.
attributes.additional_details:
We are the second largest producers of plastic waste after the USA (BBC 15/05/21). The waste is being exported to countries who unscrupulously and illegally dispose of the UK's plastic waste by dumping it in the countryside or burning it in the open causing pollution, beyond the controls of the UK once it has left our shores.
https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-57139474

departments.name: Department for Environment, Food and Rural Affairs

attributes.action: 3 Days Off A Year To Let The World Rest
attributes.background: I would like the Government to enforce a 3 day Co2 holiday in which all non essential travel (air, road and sea) is curtailed and any travel that does take place will attract an additional environmental levy that goes towards environmental initiatives. All emergency services will be exempt.
attributes.additional_details:
COVID-19 has been a tragedy but it has shown us the amazing things that can happen when you give the world a break! China has lower pollution rates and lakes are clear in Venice. 

People and the world need a break sometimes. 3 days off a year, planned and prepped, working from home where possible and closing what we can will allow our earth and our brains to breathe and take a moment to recharge ourselves.

departments.name: Department for Business, Energy and Industrial Strategy

attributes.action: Set stricter legal targets for air quality and increase funding for research
attributes.background: The Government’s planned new legal targets for air quality must align with the WHO air quality guideline levels. It should also increase funding for research and development to develop cleaner energy sources and reduce plastic air pollution from tyres. This will also help combat climate change.
attributes.additional_details:
Each year at least 28,000 people in the UK die prematurely because of air pollution, including children. Air pollution has been linked to heart disease, lung disease and cancer, and can exacerbate allergies, skin conditions and pregnancy complications. 
 
Currently we are above the World Health Organisation guideline levels for multiple pollutants. Data from the World Bank shows that 66% of the UK population were exposed to pollution above the WHO standards in 2017.

departments.name: Department for Environment, Food and Rural Affairs

attributes.action: Ban the sale of petrol and diesel cars by 2024, six years earlier than planned
attributes.background: The government's current plan is to end the sale of petrol and diesel cars by 2030. The end of 2030 is almost nine-and-a-half years away. My strongly held belief is that the UK government must act sooner. That is why I am advocating a 2024 cut-off for the sale of petrol and diesel cars.
attributes.additional_details:
It is agreed that petrol and diesel cars are bad; the consensus is that these vehicles cause illness-inducing pollution, and that they also contribute to global warming. Indeed, the danger of the vehicles is why the government's policy is to ban their sale by 2030. 

The debate concerns timing. I think that 2030 is far too distant. These cars are killing now. The climate emergency is occurring now. During times of crisis, it is incumbent to act at the earliest opportunity - and not delay.

departments.name: Department for Business, Energy and Industrial Strategy

attributes.action: Strengthen requirements for checking vehicle exhaust noise levels for the MOT
attributes.background: The Government should require that a vehicles exhaust's noise levels are checked to ascertain if they have been modified to make them louder. This should include any systems that allow the noise of the vehicle exhaust to be increased or decreased by the driver.
attributes.additional_details:
Vehicles that have been illegally modified should fail their MOT, and stations should face fines or lose of their licence if they fail to perform these checks.
 
Noise pollution from exhaust modified vehicles has an adverse effect on large numbers of households. Interrupting sleep and frightening young children. The World Health Organisation has published research quantifying the number of healthy life years lost due to environmental noise, including from road vehicles.

departments.name: Department for Transport

attributes.action: Ban the use of super trawlers in UK waters
attributes.background: We are interested in the banning of super trawlers to take a step in the right direction to heal one of our most important ecosystems. We hope this will help regulate overfishing in UK waters, and reduce the amount of fishing related plastic waste in the British Isles.
attributes.additional_details: The ocean is currently being grossly overfished, destroying many vital ecosystems which are necessary for all human life. Banning the use of super trawlers would take a very important step to healing the ocean floor, would greatly reduce fishing related plastic waste that pollutes our own waters and the ocean as a whole, and finally, would also contribute to the prevention of the accidental fishing of dolphins, sharks, and whales off of our coastline.

departments.name: Department for Environment, Food and Rural Affairs

attributes.action: Ban the use of private jets to help climate change
attributes.background: As we are constantly reminded that 'we the people' must change our living habits to produce net zero carbon emissions, let's start by banning private jets from our airspace to help lower the country's pollution.
attributes.additional_details: The people in society that can afford to travel on private jets should set an example by not using private jets to travel or commute. Unfortunately the users of private jets are hypocritical to demand change but dont act. Ban all private jets from british airspace. 50 people on 1 plane not 50 people on 50 planes.

departments.name: Department for Transport

attributes.action: Deposit scheme on  glass, plastic, steel, aluminium bottles and cans.
attributes.background: The UK government to launch a consultation on a deposit scheme that could see a refundable charge added to the cost of single-use glass, plastic, steel and aluminium bottles and cans sold in the UK in an effort to combat pollution, reduce waste and increase recycling.
attributes.additional_details: I would like to see the UK Government instigate a deposit scheme on all single-use glass, plastic, steel and aluminium bottles and cans that are sold singly or part of a multi pack in the UK. The scheme should fund a local repository and collection service that ensures the Items are recycled rather than littered across the UK Countryside, Towns and Cities. The scheme should also support research into the manufacture of biodegradable single-use glass, plastic, steel and aluminium bottles and cans. The education of the British public to engage in local conservation actions to collect, remove  and recycle these products within their local areas. I think the majority of the UK would relish the opportunity to banish the said waste products before the environmental effects  become irreversible.

departments.name: Department for Environment, Food and Rural Affairs

attributes.action: Restrict Cat 3 fireworks to professionals & require licences for Cat 2 fireworks
attributes.background: Extend restrictions on Cat 4 fireworks, which can only be used by professionals, to Cat 3 fireworks, and require personal fireworks licences - similar to those used in NI - for the purchase of Cat 2 fireworks. Retailers should be required to store licence numbers for all fireworks sold.
attributes.additional_details:
These measures should:
 
1. Reduce increasingly anti-social use of fireworks, to protect emergency responders and public.
2. Reduce amount of injuries related to fireworks (116 hospital admissions in 2020/2021, 3600 A&E visits between 2015 to 2019)
3. Reduce noxious pollutants (AQIN in 2020 shows almost tripled levels of particulate matter in some areas during bonfire night), including greenhouse gasses and heavy metals.
4. Reduce undue stress inflicted to people on the autistic spectrum, people with PTSD, and animals.

departments.name: Department for Business, Energy and Industrial Strategy

attributes.action: Ban the manufacture and sale of plastic bottles
attributes.background: We want the Government to take action to cut down plastic pollution by banning the manufacture and sale of plastic bottles, which make up a significant proportion of all plastic packaging.
attributes.additional_details: In order to tackle this problem a ban is required.

departments.name: Department for Environment, Food and Rural Affairs

attributes.action: Change the Highway Code to recommend cyclists keep left in most circumstances
attributes.background: The new Rule 72 in the Highway Code should be amended to advise cyclists to keep left at all times when cycling on the road, except when the road narrows sufficiently that it would be dangerous for vehicles to overtake and when approaching a junction or roundabout to turn right.
attributes.additional_details:
The new Rule 72 tells cyclists to "Ride in the centre of your lane, to make yourself as clearly visible as possible", when on quiet roads or streets, (unless being approached from behind by a faster vehicle), in slower-moving traffic, and at the approach to junctions or road narrowings where it would be unsafe for drivers to overtake you.

We believe the new guidance on road positioning could put cyclists and other road users in danger, and will also lead to increased pollution and energy wastage from additional braking and accelerating.

departments.name: Department for Transport

attributes.action: Make household bonfires illegal
attributes.background: Make household bonfires illegal. They are anti social, especially on warm, sunny days when we have our windows open and have washing on the line.  Bonfires can also be a major health concern to those suffering with asthma, COPD, and more recently, lung conditions caused by Covid-19.
attributes.additional_details: Nowadays we can have high levels of pollutants in the atmosphere, which makes the lives of those living with serious lung conditions a misery. Since Covid, there are more and more people living with these conditions and household fires can exacerbate their discomfort and maybe even cause life threatening results.

departments.name: Department for Environment, Food and Rural Affairs

attributes.action: Place large environmental taxes on the use of private jets
attributes.background: Hefty environmental taxes should be placed on those who decide to pollute the environment for no good reason but too show off wealth, power and status. These extra taxes can then be used to inject cash into new technologies and infrastructures to reach our target of being carbon neutral by 2050
attributes.additional_details: These small steps going to have to be implemented quickly and effectively to have any chance of combatting climate change and it consequences.

departments.name: Department for Transport

attributes.action: Require local authorities to compost all food waste
attributes.background: Make it mandatory that all food waste and compostable material is collected and composted, rather than go to landfill or incineration.
attributes.additional_details:
Food waste in landfill release methane, a more potent greenhouse gas. Production of compost, then used in farming has a number of benefits. 

Carbon is sequestered into the soil so carbon in the atmosphere is reduced. 
Soil structure is improved so desertification is reduced.
Soil has a greater ability to absorb water, so less flooding, water run off, pollution of waterways. 
Soil has more nutrients, microbes can grow, these increase the amount of carbon removed from the atmosphere.

departments.name: Department for Levelling Up, Housing and Communities

attributes.action: Ban the manufacture and sale of dog waste bags not made of plant-based material
attributes.background: Ban the manufacture and sale of plastic (including degradable) dog waste bags to reduce use of petroleum and to cut CO2 emissions and plastic pollution.
attributes.additional_details:
Millions of dog waste bags are thrown away every day. Some into trees!

The vast majority are made of plastic, and are not recyclable by their use. Even degradable plastic uses petroleum products and degrades to form CO2. 

There's a clear strategy by the vendors of the degradable bags to make them seem environmentally friendly as people don't appreciate they help cause global warming. 

Plant-based bags (e.g. corn starch) are sustainable and non-polluting. We already use them as food waste bags.

departments.name: Department for Environment, Food and Rural Affairs

attributes.action: Evenly spread the environmental charges applied to domestic gas and electricity.
attributes.background:
Currently environmental charges applied to domestic electricity are 12 times higher than those applied to gas, despite the fuels having almost identical levels of environmental impact. 
The government should spread the charges relative to the pollution caused by each fuel.
attributes.additional_details:
Electricity prices are 24% higher due to the environmental charge, whereas gas prices are only 2% higher.  
This disadvantages rural communities without gas, residents of flats and people forced to use electrical home heating.
The high charge on electricity slows the transition to Net Carbon Zero, by increasing the fuel cost for clean alternatives such as heat pumps and battery electric vehicles.
Electricity generation is becoming cleaner each year, and the charges should reflect that progress.

departments.name: Department for Business, Energy and Industrial Strategy

attributes.action: Ban non-compostable multi-layer material food packaging by 2030
attributes.background: The Government must ban non-compostable mixed material consumer food packaging by 2030. This should force manufacturers to use compostable packaging such as PLA instead for multi-layer material packaging e.g. crisp packets.
attributes.additional_details: The UK can set the example, leading change in the global market using our consumer power. Producers must adapt to a changing world, and shift to working under a circular economy. This legislation can begin this change. Although supplementary, we must look past recycling to instead reduce the use of plastic, reverse waste pollution and the growing damage of micro plastics. Our consumption can be reformed and this ambition to reduce our plastic production be realised with this call for change.

departments.name: Department for Business, Energy and Industrial Strategy

attributes.action: Fund grants for installation of solar panels and battery storage for households
attributes.background: We ask the government to provide grants to all households that wish to install solar panels and battery storage. For those on the lowest incomes we ask that the grant cover the full costs of installation so the household does not carry any financial burden.
attributes.additional_details: Total UK domestic electricity consumption = 103.8 TWh. Installing solar panels on every house in the UK would provide 60.52% of our total domestic electricity consumption. Between April and September, solar generation would exceed all domestic electricity consumption. Dangers regarding nuclear power plants are well documented, as well as upfront cost & security risks. Fracking causes air water & sound pollution, for these reasons we believe solar power to be better and worth the extra funding.

departments.name: Department for Business, Energy and Industrial Strategy

attributes.action: Make releasing helium balloons and sky lanterns a specific littering offence
attributes.background: These items are mostly non-biodegradable & have been responsible for the deaths of many animals, both wild & domestic, either from ingestion or injuries caused through panic, as well as littering the countryside. Releasing them should be a specific littering offence.
attributes.additional_details:
I was riding & found a large metallic pink deflated helium balloon stuck on the gate onto the bridleway which stopped my horse in her tracks. I jumped off, led her towards it, untangled it, rolled it up & put it under a stone to be disposed of when I got back praying all the time that it would not blow off as the wind blowing towards so it would have come straight at us, potentially causing my horse to panic & hurt or even kill herself and/or me.
 
People can be fined for littering if they throw away an apple core. How can it be legal for these things be released to pollute the countryside?

departments.name: Department for Environment, Food and Rural Affairs

attributes.action: Place large environmental taxes on the use of private jets
attributes.background: Hefty environmental taxes should be placed on those who decide to pollute the environment for no good reason but too show off wealth, power and status. These extra taxes can then be used to inject cash into new technologies and infrastructures to reach our target of being carbon neutral by 2050
attributes.additional_details: These small steps going to have to be implemented quickly and effectively to have any chance of combatting climate change and it consequences.

departments.name: Department for Transport

attributes.action: Make bikes and bicycle accessories zero-rated for VAT
attributes.background: The Government should zero-rate VAT for pedal cycles and bicycle accessories such as bike helmets, locks and lights.
attributes.additional_details: Pedal cycles, including bicycles, tricycles, tandems, etc should be zero- rated for VAT. This would reduce the cost for users, thereby encouraging their uptake and use, which should benefit the population by encouraging exercise, and the environment by reducing pollution. This should also enable social distancing and reduce reliance on public transport during the Covid-19 outbreak.

departments.name: HM Treasury

attributes.action: Set a target for 70% of UK energy to be renewable by 2030
attributes.background: We would like the Government to seek to reduce carbon emissions by considerable amounts by setting a target to increase the UK's renewable energy generation to account for 70% of all energy. By achieving this we hope to reduce pollution and the amount of carbon emissions from the UK.
attributes.additional_details: We would like to stop climate change progressing further than it's currently estimated to rise to in order to save our planet. Fossil fuels are one of the biggest contributors to climate change. Not only that but we rely on fossil fuels to complete everyday tasks. However, fossil fuels will eventually run out so we need a suitable solution to fall back on. To save ourselves and our planet we must make more use of renewable energy sources such as hydro-electric, solar and wind energy.

departments.name: Department for Environment, Food and Rural Affairs

attributes.action: Ban imports of oil from Nigeria pending human rights and sustainability reviews
attributes.background: The Government should consider a UK ban on oil imports from Nigeria, pending a full review of reported human rights abuses, so that there is no risk of revenue from UK imports being used to finance activities which breach human rights, and of the sustainability of the oil industry.
attributes.additional_details:
The UK has a unique historic and contemporary commercial interest in Nigeria. And a responsibility to intervene regarding concerns about human rights and sustainability.
The fossil fuel industry feeds massive biodiversity loss, pollution, degradation of land and water resources.
 
The Government should consider a full ban on oil exports from Nigeria until full reviews of reported human rights abuses and sustainability of the oil industry has been completed.
 
An urgent targeted response is required.

departments.name: Department for International Trade

attributes.action: Stop Operation Brock & find alternative solution to traffic build-up in Kent
attributes.background: Stop Operation Brock, in which the M20 is used to stack lorries when there is problems at Dover, and find an alternative solution to the build-up of traffic on the M20 when travel across the Channel is disrupted.
attributes.additional_details: Operation Brock can cause serious traffic problems, extra pollution and noise issues for Kent residents and awful conditions for lorry drivers. This system was once called operation stack then was rebranded to operation brock. Fundamentally the same thing, causing the same issues, there has to be a better solution, you just don’t find this sort of thing abroad because there are much better processes in place.

departments.name: Department for Transport

attributes.action: Ban plastic fishing nets in UK waters.
attributes.background: Plastic fishing gear discarded from vessels are polluting our seas and strangling wildlife. A truly biodegradable alternative needs to be rediscovered. Our oceans are a dumping ground for plastic and other rubbish; plastic fishing nets, ropes and other gear form a significant part of that pollution.
attributes.additional_details: Get plastic out of the sea, and stop any more unnecessary plastic waste including nets going into the seas. Persuade the fishing industry that fishing cannot be sustained with so much plastic waste in our oceans, including continued discarding of nets straggling and killing sea creatures.

departments.name: Department for Environment, Food and Rural Affairs

attributes.action: Ban all fishing in UK waters, except rod and line, for 5 years.
attributes.background: Recognise the importance of life in our oceans as critical to our own survival on land. Defend our natural environment and thus society, from collapse. Ban all net fishing vessels from UK waters. Furlough fisherman. Review fishing and labelling standards. Finance independent surveys on fish stocks.
attributes.additional_details:
We need drastic change now, supported by the Government and the Navy, to protect UK waters from all commercial fishing and pollution. Maybe even ban fish from being sold in the UK for 5 years too. We need to protect all ocean life to ensure the future survival of all species, which includes humans. 

The time for drastic action is now. The consequences of inaction will be absolute.

departments.name: Department for Environment, Food and Rural Affairs

attributes.action: Make public transport free like it is in Luxembourg
attributes.background: The Luxembourg government has made all public transport free to reduce air pollution, congestion and greenhouse gases. It also improves the health of the general public. It's paid for out of taxes. We should too or at least make it heavily subsidized like the buses used to be in Sheffield.
attributes.additional_details: Up until the early 1980s the buses in Sheffield were heavily subsidized to such an extent that public transport was virtually free. Very few bus fares were more than 10p. Given the failure of the COP 26 Climate change conference to deliver anything of substance we should, as a G7 country, lead by example.

departments.name: Department for Transport

attributes.action: Require packaging that clearly details the environmental impact of products.
attributes.background: Food packaging has nutritional information on the front, using a traffic light system. In a similar way, details such as mean equivalent carbon emissions, land use, water use, ecological impact and resulting pollution should be clearly visible on the front of consumer goods packaging.
attributes.additional_details: Around 26% of global emissions come from food. Most individuals don't have the time to research the environmental impact of their consumables. Implementing this policy will help consumers make more environmentally friendly choices and put pressure on companies to develop products that are better for the planet. In addition, the need for companies to assess environmental impact will result in a boom of jobs in the environment sector. Britain will lead the world in enabling green consumer choices.

departments.name: Department for Environment, Food and Rural Affairs

attributes.action: Introduce an 'Luxury Polluter' tax on high CO2 output luxury cars.
attributes.background: We the undersigned would like the government to introduce an additional annual tax on new luxury vehicles costing over £40,000 whose rated CO2 output exceeds 150g/km.
attributes.additional_details:
One of the few remaining obstacles towards the decarbonisation of our transport network is the affordability of greener vehicles. However for buyers of luxury vehicles costing over £40,000 this is not an issue as there are a great many low-emissions vehicles able to fit a variety of needs.

The goal of the proposed tax is specifically to discourage only the absolute largest, and most polluting vehicles and only among those for whom the cost of using a cleaner alternative is not a burden.

departments.name: Department for Transport

attributes.action: Halt all plans to build new roads & use money to repay coronavirus debt.
attributes.background: I don't want my children to be burdened by the huge debt this virus has caused. After this crisis more people are likely to work from home as companies have invested in technology to enable this so there should be less traffic. Work hours could be staggered reducing traffic & the need for new roads.
attributes.additional_details: Higher taxes & pay freezes would demoralize people after this terrible virus. Cancel all new road building and encourage people to work from home and stagger working hours. New roads can increase traffic because people think their journey time will be shortened. People should be encouraged to use public transport or bikes. Air and noise pollution caused by cars should also be reduced. Higher taxes will affect everyone, new roads will affect considerably less.

departments.name: Department for Transport

attributes.action: Make all noise nuisances between 23:00 and 07:00 a criminal offence
attributes.background: Noise nuisances are mostly handled by local councils and can have very long resolution times. We need the police to be empowered to deal with all noise nuisances as they occur, rather than local authorities taking action once the anti-social behaviour has already caused distress.
attributes.additional_details:
Excessive noise pollution can mean children struggle to get a good night’s sleep, hardworking people’s lives are made more stressful, and is proven to cause physical and mental health issues.
 
We want all forms of noise pollution, such as music and parties, between the hours of 23:00 and 07:00 to be made a criminal offence, so action can be taken by the police.

departments.name: Home Office

attributes.action: Legislate to restrict aircraft from running their engines while on hold
attributes.background: We ask the Govt to urgently bring forward legislation restricting aircraft from being on hold on a taxiway with their engines running. They should also be pulled using electric trucks to minimise pollution and noise to the immediate area.
attributes.additional_details:
Having planes on hold with their engines running leads to increased emissions and affects neighbouring areas.
 
Planes are emit far more pollution than any other forms of transport, and allowing aircraft to run their engines while on hold enables further emissions unnecessarily.

departments.name: Department for Transport

attributes.action: Change framework for clean air zones so Euro 5 Diesel do not have to be charged
attributes.background: The Government framework for clean air zones should be amended to allow Euro 5 diesel cars can be included within the standards for these zones.
attributes.additional_details: These cars are low pollution cars and should not be excluded from clean air zones by the Government’s framework.

departments.name: Department for Transport

attributes.action: Ban fast food companies from using disposable packaging for advertising
attributes.background: Companies should not be allowed to use disposable single use takeaway containers for advertising their brand.  All takeaway food and drink containers must instead only display information regarding the correct disposal of the used packaging and providing this information should be mandatory.
attributes.additional_details: Takeaway food packaging is huge problem for the planet, causing litter and plastic pollution on both land and sea. Currently companies do not discourage the use of this single use packaging as it provides a far reaching opportunity for widespread community advertising both when the packaging is in use and when it is littered. Once packaging doesn't work for them, then companies will look to cut costs by encouraging refillable and reusable packaging solutions instead.

departments.name: Department for Environment, Food and Rural Affairs

attributes.action: A yearly 2 week period where everything shuts down to let the world heal
attributes.background: All non essential travel including vehicular, public transport, flights and cruises, non essential businesses, schools, pubs, bars, restaurants, to be closed, to reduce our carbon footprint and let the earth heal, to increase social consciousness and community spirit and to promote family focus
attributes.additional_details: We have already seen in the short space of time during the Covid-19 pandemic, improvements in pollution levels around the world (Venice canals cleaner for example), communities are banding together and supporting each other more and families are spending more time with each other outside of regular holiday periods. We have to commit to reducing our carbon footprint and this episode, albeit under drastic measures, has shown that a positive can come out of reduced public activity.

departments.name: Department for Business, Energy and Industrial Strategy

attributes.action: Remove Vehicle Excise Duty and add the cost to Fuel Duty
attributes.background: Abolish Vehicle Excise Duty and add the cost to a litre of fuel, so the more economical the vehicle you drive - the less you pay. This should encourage people to drive more responsibly and also benefit the environment.
attributes.additional_details: To encourage people to drive less polluting vehicles and also making the people that use the roads most pay more for their upkeep.

departments.name: HM Treasury

attributes.action: Ban sale and use of Leaf Blowers
attributes.background: Ban the sale and use of leaf blowers throughout the UK. They are noisy, polluting, can kill small animals, and can easily be replaced with more quiet, environmentally friendly gardening tools.
attributes.additional_details:
Petrol powered leaf blowers can emit massive amounts of pollution - hydrocarbons and nitrogen oxides as well as carbon monoxide.

Even when electric alternatives are used, they cause noise disturbance and distress to both people and wildlife. Additionally, many small animals can be injured or killed due to leaf blowing, in particular insects.

departments.name: Department for Environment, Food and Rural Affairs

attributes.action: Ban trade deals with countries that deny climate change or not meeting targets.
attributes.background: To make it illegal to engage in the formation of international trade agreements with countries that either (a) deny the process and threat of climate change (b) refuse to ratify internationally agreed climate goals (e.g. Paris Agreement or Kyoto Protocol) or (c) are not working to meet those goals.
attributes.additional_details: Climate change is an existential threat to our world and to business as normal. Pursuing business as normal with countries that are not engaging positively with the impact of climate change will severely impact the well being of everyone and the GDP of all countries. It is irresponsible to reward and encourage countries that deny climate change or are not engaging with pollution reduction with trade deals. As the UK wants to be a global leader on climate change, these deals should not be made.

departments.name: Department for International Trade

attributes.action: Ban the use of virgin plastics in all packaging sold in the UK before 2023
attributes.background: Parliament should pass legislation banning the use of virgin plastics (plastics made directly from petrochemicals rather than recycled plastic) in all product packaging sold in the UK by the end of 2022.
attributes.additional_details:
The UK produces more plastic waste than almost all other countries worldwide. Current schemes for plastic recycling do not work, with most UK waste sent overseas, where it is burnt or dumped in the seas, destroying human, plant and animal habitats. 

By banning virgin plastics, manufacturers will be forced to use recycled materials, creating a circular economy that increases the value of recycled plastic that in turn should ensure proper recycling, and reduced pollution and petrochemical use.

departments.name: Department for Business, Energy and Industrial Strategy

attributes.action: Ban the use of non recyclable plastics in food/drink packaging
attributes.background:
I would like to ban the use of non recyclable plastics in food/drink packaging. These plastics can take hundreds of years to biodegrade.

 By using recyclable plastics. we can take another step to eradicate single use plastics altogether.
attributes.additional_details:
Plastic is widely known to be harmful to the environment.
It can take thousands of years to biodegrade. Pollute our oceans harming marine life.
By helping to eradicate single use plastic today. You can help make a better tomorrow

attributes.action: Change our time zone to Single/Double British Summertime (SDST)
attributes.background: Around 1 in 3 people suffer from Seasonal Affective Disorder in the UK; moving on to SDST could greatly combat this. Rather than wasting the precious hour of light in the morning, on a commute or in an office, we could utilise it in the evening, after work, for socialising and outdoor activities.
attributes.additional_details:
The key benefits:

Health: SAD could be reduced as people could use the longer evenings to socialise and engage in leisure activities such as sport.

Safety: It could prevent 80 deaths and more than 200 serious injuries on UK roads every year.

Environment: CO2 pollution could be reduced by at least 447,000 tonnes each year, due to a lower electricity demand for artificial light in the evenings.

Tourism: UK tourism industry could be boosted by £1bn every year due to longer and lighter days.

departments.name: Department for Business, Energy and Industrial Strategy

attributes.action: Make it compulsory for schools and workplaces to have recycling bins
attributes.background: Recycling saves energy as it reduces the need for extracting, refining and processing materials all of which create air & water pollution, and greenhouse gas emissions. Recycling can help tackle climate change, and schools and workplaces should be required to have recycling bins to help with this.
attributes.additional_details: Additionally, recycling is a diverse industry and when compared to waste disposal it is much more labour intensive. This means building the recycling industry is also a way to create more jobs. It is said that disposing of 10,000 tons of waste in a landfill creates six jobs, as opposed to recycling the same amount of waste, which creates 36 jobs. Overall, there are many benefits to be derived from recycling and schools and workplaces should be required to contribute to recycling.

attributes.action: Change the law on airport slots to favour ecological practices
attributes.background:
Under international guidelines and EU law companies keep their landing slots if they use them over 80% of the time in UK's major airports.

During the covid-19 crisis this is resulting in ghost (empty) flights.
attributes.additional_details:
UK law should priorities positive ecological practices both during and post the crisis.
 
The House of Commons has announced a climate change emergency.
 
Aircraft engines emit particulates and gases into the atmosphere which contributes to climate change.
In times of low international travel (such as now, during covid-19 outbreak) planes should not fly empty.
 
Laws such as the 80% slot usage leads to economical incentive for airlines to fly empty planes because slots are valuable. This practice should be stopped. The priority should be to reduce pollution not support big airlines.

departments.name: Department for Transport

attributes.action: Extend the ban on plastic microbeads and other microplastics
attributes.background: To reduce plastic pollution and encourage businesses to produce greener products I would like the Government to extend the ban on the use of plastic microbeads to include leave-on cosmetic products, and also ban the use of microplastic emulsifiers.
attributes.additional_details: Extending the current ban on the amount of microplastics used in our products should have many benefits: It should reduce the amount of virgin plastic being produced, reduce plastic pollution in our oceans and other ecosystems, reduce the adverse health effects microplastics can have on humans and animals, and incentivise research into plastic free/ bioplastic alternatives. Reducing dependence on plastics and protecting marine ecosystems could also help the UK reach its net zero carbon targets.
